questions.question_text_1: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 42,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk, what should be the maximum speed of disk in RPM so that the lens does not miss any data?
question_texts: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 42,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk, what should be the maximum speed of disk in RPM so that the lens does not miss any data?

options.option_text: Statements i and iii are correct
Statements ii and iv are correct
The tables are not at all related

questions.question_text_1: Read the statements given below carefully and select the correct option.  Statement 1:If an element having an ID and a class is styled externally using both its ID and the class, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest selector in order.  Statement 2: If an element that belongs to two different classes is styled externally using both the classes, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest class in order
question_texts: Read the statements given below carefully and select the correct option.  Statement 1:If an element having an ID and a class is styled externally using both its ID and the class, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest selector in order.  Statement 2: If an element that belongs to two different classes is styled externally using both the classes, then for the same attribute, it will acquire styling from the latest class in order

options.option_text: Statement 1 is correct but statement 2 is incorrect
Statement 2 is correct but statement 1 is incorrect

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following graph that represents the variation in bandwidth of a network for an entire day (24 hours). Three users were connected to the network at three different times of the day. What is the total data consumed in GigaBytes by all the users in 24 hrs?

questions.question_text_1: You have a DRAM module with bus width of 64 bits, clock speed of 2 GHz, and operating in DDR (double-data-rate or two values per clock cycle) mode. What is the maximum bandwidth (in Giga-bytes per second) of data transfer achievable with this module?

options.option_text: The server keeps the state of the client to respond to the required request.
Server use variant HTTP methods to respond to the client's request.
Server ready to respond to the client's request without knowing anythingabout the client.
Server use the URL to convey context to the client.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development I"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** ### **1. Python & Flask Fundamentals** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Command-line arguments (`sys.argv`)** - Accessing arguments: `sys.argv[0]` (script name), `sys.argv[1:]` (user inputs). - Example: ```python import sys var_a, var_b = sys.argv[1], sys.argv[2] ``` - **Jinja2 Templating** - Rendering dynamic content: ```python template = Template("{{ var_a }} is {{ var_b }}") print(template.render(var_a="Meera", var_b="Data Analyst")) ``` - Conditional rendering in HTML: ```html {% if error %}

Access denied

{% else %}

Welcome

{% endif %} ``` - **Flask Routing & Request Handling** - Dynamic routes: ```python @app.route('/details//') def get_details(id, name): return f"ID: {id}, Name: {name}" ``` - Query parameters: ```python @app.route('/calculate') def calculate(): a = request.args.get('a') operator = request.args.get('operator') ``` - HTTP methods (`GET`, `POST`): ```python @app.route('/submit', methods=['POST']) def submit(): data = request.form['data'] ``` - Error handling: ```python @app.errorhandler(404) def not_found(error): return "Page not found", 404 ``` - **Flask-RESTful & Request Parsing** - Parsing JSON/form data: ```python parser = reqparse.RequestParser() parser.add_argument("val") args = parser.parse_args() ``` - Returning JSON responses: ```python return {"Course_1": args["val"], "Course_2": request.args.get("val")} ``` #### **Key Equations/Logic:** - **URL matching in Flask:** - `/route/` → Matches integers. - `/route/` → Matches strings. - `/route/` → Matches multi-segment paths. --- ### **2. HTML/CSS & Jinja2** #### **Key Concepts:** - **CSS Specificity Hierarchy** - `!important` > Inline styles > IDs (`#id`) > Classes (`.class`) > Elements (`span`). - Example: ```css #id { color: blue; } /* Higher priority than class */ .class { color: red; } ``` - **Jinja2 Macros & Loops** - Defining macros: ```html {% macro unordered_list(items) %}
    {% for item in items %}
  • {{ item }}
    • {% endfor %}
{% endmacro %} ``` - Conditional rendering: ```html {% if item|length >= 5 %}
  • {{ item }}
    • {% endif %} ``` - **Template Inheritance** - Base template (`base.html`): ```html {% block content %}{% endblock %} ``` - Child template (`home.html`): ```html {% extends "base.html" %} {% block content %}

    MAD I

    {% endblock %} ``` #### **Key Equations/Logic:** - **CSS Box Model:** - `Total Width = width + padding + border + margin` - `Total Height = height + padding + border + margin` --- ### **3. Databases & SQLAlchemy** #### **Key Concepts:** - **SQLAlchemy Models & Relationships** - One-to-Many: ```python class Library(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) books = db.relationship("Book", backref="library") class Book(db.Model): library_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey("library.id")) ``` - Many-to-Many (requires association table). - **CRUD Operations** - Adding records: ```python db.session.add(user1) db.session.commit() ``` - Querying: ```python User.query.filter_by(username="Rakesh").first() ``` - Deleting: ```python db.session.delete(user1) db.session.commit() ``` #### **Key Equations/Logic:** - **Foreign Key Constraints:** - `db.ForeignKey("table.column")` links tables. --- ### **4. Testing with Pytest** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Test Functions & Assertions** - Basic test: ```python def test_addition(): assert 1 + 1 == 2 ``` - Parameterized tests: ```python @pytest.mark.parametrize("input,expected", [(3, 9), (5, 25)]) def test_square(input, expected): assert square(input) == expected ``` - **Fixtures** - Reusable setup: ```python @pytest.fixture def sample_data(): return {"a": 1, "b": 2} ``` - **Markers & Selection** - Running specific tests: ```bash pytest -m marker1 # Runs tests with @pytest.mark.marker1 pytest -k "Test_class" # Runs tests with "Test_class" in name ``` #### **Key Equations/Logic:** - **Test Output Interpretation:** - `1 passed, 3 deselected` → Only marked tests ran. - `1 failed, 4 passed` → One assertion failed. --- ### **5. Networking & Performance** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Bandwidth & Data Transfer** - **Total Data (bits) = Bandwidth (bits/sec) × Time (sec)** - Example: 10 Mbps × 3600 sec = 36,000 Mb (4.5 GB). - **Latency Calculation** - **Round-Trip Time (RTT) = (Distance / Speed) × 2** - Example: 9000 km cable (speed = 1.5×10⁸ m/s) + 9000 km air (speed = 3×10⁸ m/s): ``` RTT = (9×10⁶ / 1.5×10⁸) + (9×10⁶ / 3×10⁸) = 0.06 + 0.03 = 0.09 sec → 90 ms ``` - **DRAM Bandwidth** - **Bandwidth (GB/s) = (Bus Width × Clock Speed × 2) / 8** - Example: 64-bit bus, 2 GHz DDR: ``` (64 × 2×10⁹ × 2) / 8 = 32 GB/s ``` #### **Key Equations:** | Concept | Equation | |-----------------------|-------------------------------------------| | Data Transfer | `Data (bits) = Bandwidth × Time` | | Latency | `Time = Distance / Speed` | | DRAM Bandwidth | `Bandwidth (GB/s) = (Width × Freq × 2)/8` | --- ### **6. HTTP & Statelessness** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Stateless Protocol** - Server does not store client state between requests. - Uses **cookies/sessions** for persistence: ```python from flask import session session['user'] = "admin" # Set session ``` - **HTTP Methods** - `GET`: Retrieve data. - `POST`: Submit data. - `PUT/PATCH`: Update data. - `DELETE`: Remove data. - **Status Codes** - `200 OK`: Success. - `400 Bad Request`: Client error. - `401 Unauthorized`: Authentication failed. - `404 Not Found`: Resource missing. - `500 Server Error`: Server-side issue. --- ### **7. Software Testing Types** | Type | Description | |-----------------------|----------------------------------------------| | **Regression Testing** | Ensures new changes don’t break existing functionality. | | **User Acceptance Testing (UAT)** | Validates software with end-users (e.g., beta testing). | | **System Testing** | Tests the complete system (hardware + software). | | **System Testing Automation** | Automates system tests (e.g., Selenium for browser testing). | --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **1. Flask & Web Development Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask] --> B[Routing] A --> C[Templating with Jinja2] A --> D[Request Handling] A --> E[Error Handling] B --> F[Dynamic Routes: /user/] B --> G[Query Parameters: ?key=value] C --> H[Macros] C --> I[Template Inheritance] D --> J[GET/POST Methods] D --> K[Form/Data Parsing] E --> L[Custom Error Pages: 404, 400] ``` ### **2. HTML/CSS & Jinja2 Relationships** ```mermaid graph TD A[HTML] --> B[CSS Styling] A --> C[Jinja2 Templating] B --> D[Specificity: ID > Class > Element] B --> E[Box Model: Margin/Border/Padding] C --> F[Conditionals: {% if %}] C --> G[Loops: {% for %}] C --> H[Macros: {% macro %}] ``` ### **3. Database & SQLAlchemy** ```mermaid graph TD A[SQLAlchemy] --> B[Models] A --> C[Relationships] A --> D[CRUD Operations] B --> E[db.Model] B --> F[db.Column] C --> G[One-to-Many] C --> H[Many-to-Many] D --> I[db.session.add()] D --> J[db.session.commit()] ``` ### **4. Testing with Pytest** ```mermaid graph TD A[Pytest] --> B[Test Functions] A --> C[Fixtures] A --> D[Markers] A --> E[Parameterized Tests] B --> F[assert statements] C --> G[Reusable Setup] D --> H[@pytest.mark.marker1] E --> I[@pytest.mark.parametrize] ``` ### **5. Networking & Performance** ```mermaid graph TD A[Networking] --> B[Bandwidth] A --> C[Latency] A --> D[DRAM] B --> E[Data = Bandwidth × Time] C --> F[RTT = 2 × (Distance/Speed)] D --> G[Bandwidth = (Width × Freq × 2)/8] ``` ### **6. HTTP & Statelessness** ```mermaid graph TD A[HTTP] --> B[Stateless] A --> C[Methods] A --> D[Status Codes] B --> E[Cookies/Sessions] C --> F[GET/POST/PUT/DELETE] D --> G[200/400/404/500] ``` --- ## **Key Equations Summary (Math/Performance)** | **Concept** | **Equation** | **Example** | |---------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------| | **Data Transfer** | `Data (bits) = Bandwidth (bps) × Time (s)` | 10 Mbps × 3600 s = 36,000 Mb (4.5 GB) | | **Latency** | `Time (s) = Distance (m) / Speed (m/s)` | 9000 km / (1.5×10⁸ m/s) = 0.06 s | | **DRAM Bandwidth** | `Bandwidth (GB/s) = (Bus Width × Freq × 2)/8`| (64 × 2×10⁹ × 2)/8 = 32 GB/s | | **Disk RPM Calculation** | `RPM = (Bits/sec) / (Bits/revolution) × 60` | (42,000 bps) / (600 bits) × 60 = 4200 RPM |
